plan: I will start by testing the dominant strategy of bidding 50% of my value for a few rounds to establish a baseline. Then, I'll explore aggressive bidding by placing bids at 70% of my value to test potential higher profits. I'll also try conservative bidding at 30% to assess risk minimization. In later rounds, I will adjust my strategy based on observed patterns from Betty and Charles, potentially exploiting any predictable behaviors. I'll document outcomes to refine my approach, aiming to balance risk and reward for optimal long-term profit.

In the initial rounds, I'll test the dominant strategy of bidding 50% of my value to gather baseline data. Concurrently, I'll explore slightly aggressive bids at 60-70% of my value to assess potential profit gains. If the competition bids conservatively, I'll try a higher bid approach, reaching up to 80% of my value, to exploit their caution. I'll also occasionally bid just below my value to test riskier strategies. Throughout, I'll analyze competitors' patterns to adapt dynamically, aiming to maximize long-term profit by fine-tuning bids based on observed outcomes and rival behaviors.

I will start by bidding 50% of my value, as economists suggest. In early rounds, I will experiment with aggressive bids at 70-80% of my value to gather data on the other bidders' strategies. I will also test conservative bids at 30-40% to understand the risk of losing. Mid-game, I will analyze patterns in Andy's and Betty's bids to adjust my strategy. If they consistently bid high, I will consider underbidding to avoid losses. Towards the end, I will optimize bids based on cumulative data, aiming for a balance between risk and reward to maximize long-term profit.

Test 50% value bids for consistency. Try 70% value bids for higher profits, especially with high values. Experiment with 30% bids for risk minimization. Adjust based on Betty's and Charles's patterns, exploiting predictability. Document outcomes to refine strategy, balancing risk and reward for optimal long-term profit.
